body: For this PR and also for #4549, it would be nice to hear from @matplotlib that their docs build and are highlighted correctly still.  I've done some testing, but they aren't nearly as comprehensive.
Pinging @mdboom @ivanov to test this with the matplotlib docs.
Should we re-ping matplotlib ? open an issue on their side so that they check ?

> Should we re-ping matplotlib ? open an issue on their side so that they check ?

Probably the second option, to get more attention...

I'm not sure I follow.  matplotlib's documentation does not use the `ipython_directive`.  It uses the older/simpler `ipython_console_highlighting` plugin (included with matplotlib) that does nothing but the syntax highlighting part.

You do seem to still have [ipython_directive](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/master/lib/matplotlib/sphinxext/ipython_directive.py) and https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3352 and related was done based on your suggestion. So I thought you were using IPython directive if IPython is availlable.
Sorry, folks, and thanks for the reminder.  Not enough coffee yesterday.  I'll look into implementing using IPython's directives if they are available and see what, if anything, breaks.

Yes, matplotlib still includes the `ipython_directive` (and it's probably time to deprecate and then remove it there), but it is not used to build our own docs (never has been, as far as I know), so I think this PR is irrelevant as far as checking against matplotlib.

OK, great thanks, no problem for the reminder I had to dig into issues to find it myself.
So I guess we can go ahead with this one and have further fix later on if there are issues on matplotlib side. 
I'll let that open a few more hours for other dev to have a look.

Related -- this is a PR to use IPython's `ipython_console_highlighting` extension, if it's available:

https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/2656
pandas is using the IPython directive in their docs if we want someone to test it.

> pandas is using the IPython directive in their docs if we want someone to test it.

So we should ping @wesm I guess. (BTW, Wes if you read this, I had to export some data for biologists, I love you for having a `DataFrame.to_excel`)

I think other people do a lot of the development on pandas now, but I'm not sure who's most relevant. Maybe @jorisvandenbossche , who [updated ipython_directive a few months ago](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/commit/8d834fd9bb5703e3b72cd7141bda3fba5eccb767). Or maybe one of us should just grab the pandas repo, substitute in the IPython directive extension from this PR, and try building the docs. I have a checkout of pandas, I can probably give that a try later.

I can try it later this weekend to build the pandas docs with this, but at the moment we are not using the IPython's sphinx extension itself, but an older and in the meanwhile slightly adapted version included in pandas source. See https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/5221 for some discussion about using IPython's instead our own version. For most of the docs this already works (eg not for the cython doc page, as for this the directive was adapted). So I can give it a try.
Thanks Joris. If it's not too difficult to merge pandas' changes with the changes here and check that it still builds OK, that would be good.

I tried it out, and I don't see more problems with this PR than with version in master :-) 
To say, there are some issues with using the IPython's version, but that is both for master and this PR. I summarised them at the issue https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/5221, and they seem not to difficult to merge them here.

So for me, this PR is OK (but I didn't really look at the code and I didn't test the doctest part, as this is not used in pandas). However I have the following remark:
- regarding the default imports in `ipython_execlines`. Is it necessary to have a default value? And more particularly the pylab one `from pylab import *`? For some reason this seems to screw up a part of our docs because pylab imports the datetime module. Off course we can set this to an empty list, but I think more in general `from pylab import *` should not be encouraged?
- The usage of default / None seems different for mplbackend and execlines: For `ipython_mplbackend` setting it at None imports nothing (while default is 'agg'), while for `ipython_execlines` setting this at None imports the default. Is this None necessary for `ipython_execlines`? Why not simply have: when not specified in conf.py default to the default ['import ...'], otherwise use the one listed in conf.py?

I'll take a look at https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/5221 in the next day or so.  There are also a few other things I'd like to do before this is merged (holidays have distracted me).

Regarding the options, I'm happy to change them to whatever is decided upon.  My rationale for having the import \* was only because it was in there already. I'd be just as happy setting the default to an empty list, but if we are to have a default, then I'm definitely in agreement on the starred-import: it should be discouraged.  My suggestion for `import matplotlib.pyplot as plt` was a compromise...but I'd really like to remove the import \* statement altogether.

As for defaults, that's a good idea.  I'll make the change. Also, I'll probably make a non-backend require the string 'none', and change it so that `None` (the singleton) will keep the default.

If this and #4549 are still open on Monday, I'll do another quick sanity check on them, then take a merge-em-and-see-who-complains approach. If anyone disagrees, you've got the weekend to let me know. ;-)
:+1: to both
:+1: too

Two more remarks/questions:
- Maybe keep the default for matplotlib as `agg` as it was before? Or this would not cause backward incompatibilities for people using this directive?
- I am in favor of ditching the `from pylab import *` as default, but good to replace it with `import matplotlib.pyplot as plt` (or otherwise using `[]` as default).
I would definitely keep `matplotlib.use('agg')` here.  It's the only backend that will work in headless situations, and generating docs is often done that way.
Ahh, so the idea would be that by including use() we mean to _override_ whatever default the user might have setup.

Yes -- it would override the fault.  But it's a reasonable thing to do, since any other choice the user could make is unlikely to work, since they are all GUI-based (other than the file-backends, pdf, svg, and ps, which are used by agg automatically anyway).

Ok, so it seems we are moving closer to what was there originally:

If `ipython_mplbackend` is not specified in `conf.py`, then assume `'agg'`.  If `ipython_mplbackend` is specified as `None`, interpret this as the user saying 'Give me the default', and so, we use `'agg'` again.  If `ipython_mplbackend` is specified as `'none'`, then we do not import matplotlib at all (except if they ask for it in execlines or make use of the figure decorator).

Is this acceptable?

Good question.  I'll take a look, but probably it does not. Matplotlib does treat `None` differently from `'none'` (e.g. setting edgecolor='none'), so there's that.  But I agree that making `None` mean "no Matplotlib, no backend" would be ideal.  So, let me just do that then...we'll just make it clear that if people want the default, then they should omit the option from their conf.py.

This is mostly ready now (hopefully). I also added much improved error messages when one of the doctests fails. Instead of just showing the expected and actual outcome, it additionally shows the source file, the uninterpreted input.

There is one more bug I'm having trouble tracking down. You can see the effect here: http://docs.dit.io/en/latest/measures/shannon.html   What happens is the that `InteractiveShell.run_cell()` is executed and the output of the execution is stored in `self.cout` (see the method `EmbeddedSphinxShell.process_input_line`).  Before `run_cell` is called, `self.cout` is empty.  For the linked example, it contains `' Out[3]: 0.0'` afterwards.  The problem is the space that shouldn't be there.  It's not always inserted, but it seems to be inserted regularly (scroll down the linked page to see further examples).  Anyone know why this might be happening?  I don't think it is the directive...might be something in `InteractiveShell`.

I tested it, and it seems good!

The issue with the `' Out[]'` prompt, I am also seeing that. However, this also occurs with ipython master, so has not to do with your changes in this PR. But it still needs to be solved of course. 
The strange thing is, when I build the pandas docs, I see one file where the Out prompts are as expected (but I don't see why this file would be different) and in all the other files, it is only in the beginning, eg `' Out[10]'`, but once the prompt number is above 100, it is ok (`'Out[100]'`). Maybe this helps.
Yeah its a strange bug.  Let's punt on that for now and I'll file a bug report.
